TextView.android:text: Gallery 6 - Caves of Qumran. In 1947, three Bedouin shepherds looking for some lost sheep wandered into a cave similar to this one on the shores of the Dead Sea, and made one of the important discoveries of the twentieth century. In the cave they found a number of ancient Hebrew manuscripts hundreds of years older than the oldest Biblical manuscripts in Hebrew known at that time. These manuscripts are now known as the Dead Sea Scrolls. Most scholars agree that these writings belong to a Jewish sectarian group called the Essenes who likely occupied the caves around Qumran from the mid Third Century BC until around A.D. 70. This room is a replica of cave 4, one of the most famous caves at Khirbet Qumran. Tens of thousands of manuscripts have been recovered from the caves in which they were stored.
